com.prodp.apsim
Class APArrayUtils

java.lang.Object
  com.prodp.apsim.APObject
      com.prodp.apsim.APArrayUtils

public class APArrayUtils
extends APObject

This class contains many important array utilities and methods that are necessary for processing (game internals). The Flagger associated with this class is to make sure that the method doReqCheckLoopActions(APProcess, int) does not call more than #LIMIT. The indices array is used to label what blocks are around the current block. The indices of the block (around the block) are put into this array (the index of the block means the position of the block in the coordinate array and the HashMaps associated with it). See APProcess for more info.

getFlagger

public static final Flagger getFlagger()
Returns the Flagger associated. See Flagger for more information about flaggers.

Returns:
fl a Flagger

findEmptySpace

public static final int findEmptySpace(short[] a)
Finds the first occurence of an empty space in the status array. Emptiness is defined as having an occurence of APMaterial.NULL, which is represented by the integer 0.

Parameters:
a - the status array to be checked containing the material ids of each block.
Returns:
i the index of the empty space, or -1 if there is no empty space.

setCoordBlocks

public static final void setCoordBlocks(float[] block,
                                        int index)
Sets the other 23 vertices of the cube to their respective coordinates. Since a cube has 24 vertices, and there is an x, y, z tuple for every vertex, this method copies a float array containing {x, y, z, x + XUNIT, y, z, x + XYUNIT, y + XYUNIT, z, ...} into 72 places such that XUNIT is a tuple containing (UNIT, 0, 0), XYUNIT is (UNIT, UNIT, 0), and so on with YUNIT, ZUNIT, XZUNIT, YZUNIT, and XYZUNIT. UNIT is an arbitrary float. To put it visually: 
          h_____________g
         /|            /|
        e_|___________f |
        | |           | |
        | |           | |
        | |           | |
        | d___________|_c
        |/            |/
        a_____________b
With a cube of this dimension, the point represented by "a" in this diagram represents the point (x, y, z). b is (x + XUNIT, y, z) c is (x + XZUNIT, y, z + XZUNIT) ... e is (x, y + YUNIT, z). Note to developer: (X)(Y)(Z)UNIT is represented by BOX(X)(Y)(Z).

Parameters:
block - the array containing all the cube coordinates
index - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

setColorBlocks

public static final void setColorBlocks(byte[] color,
                                        APMaterial a,
                                        int index)
Sets the other 23 vertices of the cube to their respective colors. Since a cube has 24 vertices, and there is an r, g, b, a tuple for every vertex, this method copies a byte array containing the 96 bytes containing the red, green, blue, and alpha values of the APMaterial colors.

Parameters:
color - the array containing all the block colors
a - the APMaterial containing the color of the block
index - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

isAroundLiquid

public static final int isAroundLiquid(APProcess process,
                                       int distance,
                                       int index)
Checks if there is liquid (defined in APMaterial) around the block in a certain radius. This is necessary, separate from the computeAroundIndices(APProcess, int) process since that method only computes indices around the block with a radius of 1.

Parameters:
process - the current APProcess (screen)
distance - the radius of which to check around in
index - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes
Returns:
the index of the first occurence of a liquid or -1 if none

performReactions

public static final void performReactions(APProcess process,
                                          int i)
Uses the APReaction list from the APReactionList associated with the APProcessHandler, and processes the reactions on the specified block, if any. It takes the current APMaterial of the specific block by converting it to an APMaterial from a short via #getMaterialByID(short). It loops through the blocks around the current block, and if it isn't null (-1), it tries to search for the APPair of the material of the current block, and the material of the block around it. If this is found in the reactions list, it runs a check to see if a random float is less than the chance of the reaction. If it passes these tests, it gets the action of the reaction, an int, and when passed through a switch block, it can: Change the block to another block, or Remove the block.

Parameters:
process - the current APProcess (screen)
i - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

exchangeDensities

public static void exchangeDensities(APProcess process,
                                     int index)
Makes some blocks sink if they are heavier than the block below them. NOTE: 16, in the list of indices is the top center block. The process checks the block above the current block to see if it is lighter or heavier, similar to what was discribed above. The number 16, substituted for the definitely harder method of checking the top block's index, has speed benefits.

Parameters:
process - the current APProcess (screen)
index - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

computeAroundIndices

public static void computeAroundIndices(APProcess process,
                                        int index)
Computes the blocks around the current block. Since it is O(n^3), it is quite costly, but it only iterates over 27-1 = 26 indices. Even so, the 3 nested loops cause problems. This process takes each coordinate around the block and searches in the coordinate array to see if it exists.

Parameters:
process - the current APProcess (screen)
index - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

doReqCheckLoopActions

public static void doReqCheckLoopActions(APProcess process,
                                         int i)
Container method for all the processing requiring checking the status of the block via loop actions. Does some preliminary work with some other functions and then tries to move the block to the specified position dictated by the velocity. The velocities are CHECKED before the move, so any Newtonic forces associated with Newton's 3rd Law of Motion are already covered in the previous functions.

Parameters:
process - the current APProcess (screen)
i - the index of the current box focused on out of all the boxes

clearFlagger

public static void clearFlagger()
Clears the Flagger associated with the utility.
